page.title: 16BATEMAN'S
page.content: This Jacobean house is thought to have been built for a prosperous Wealden Ironmaster and was completed in 1634, it is built of local sand- stone. Its most famous inhabitant to date was the author Rudyard Kipling, who purchased it in 1902 and lived at Bateman's until his death in 1936 with his American wife and their three children. Upon her death she left the House to the National Trust in loving memory of her husband. Today the Mill, House, Garaging and Gardens are open to the public, who can enjoy the peace and tranquility of Kipings' home in the Sussex country- side that he loved and wrote about. Many of the spots within the house itself, the garden and locality are easily recognizable in the material he published while living at Bateman's.
